purpose: Starter list of beginner-friendly asset websites for a first game, prioritized for free + commercially-allowed usage. Always verify the specific asset license before shipping.

license_quick_rules.best_for_beginners: CC0 (public domain style) - simplest for commercial use, no attribution needed.
license_quick_rules.usually_ok_but_you_must_credit: CC BY - commercial allowed, attribution required.
license_quick_rules.avoid_for_commercial_games: NC (NonCommercial) - not allowed for commercial projects.
license_quick_rules.be_careful: SA (ShareAlike) or GPL - can add obligations that beginners often misunderstand.

kenney.name: Kenney
kenney.short_description: Curated game-ready packs (2D, 3D, UI, audio). Very beginner-friendly, consistent style, great for prototypes.
kenney.license_notes: Commonly CC0 (no attribution required). Some packs are paid bundles, but many high-quality free packs exist.
kenney.beginner_tip: Use Kenney for speed: consistent style avoids art mismatch problems.

opengameart.name: OpenGameArt
opengameart.short_description: Large library of community-made 2D, audio, and some 3D. Good breadth, but licensing is mixed per asset.
opengameart.license_notes: Licenses vary (CC0, CC BY, CC BY-SA, GPL, etc). You must filter and avoid NC for commercial releases.
opengameart.beginner_tip: Only download if the license matches your game. Prefer CC0 first, then CC BY if you can credit.

pixabay.name: Pixabay
pixabay.short_description: Huge library of free audio (music + sound effects). Easy downloads, beginner-friendly licensing summary.
pixabay.license_notes: Generally usable commercially without attribution, but watch out for restrictions around trademarks/logos and standalone redistribution.
pixabay.beginner_tip: Good default for quick music and SFX, but avoid anything that contains recognizable brands.

freesound.name: Freesound
freesound.short_description: Massive sound effect database. Best when you filter strictly for CC0 for commercial projects.
freesound.license_notes: Mixed licenses per sound (CC0, Attribution, NonCommercial). Commercial use depends on each sound’s license.
freesound.beginner_tip: Search and filter for CC0 only if you want the simplest legal path.

sonniss_gdc.name: Sonniss GameAudioGDC (Free yearly bundles)
sonniss_gdc.short_description: High-quality, huge SFX bundles released yearly. Great quality, less searchable than Freesound/Pixabay.
sonniss_gdc.license_notes: Royalty-free and commercially usable; generally no attribution required. Not intended for reselling sounds standalone.
sonniss_gdc.beginner_tip: Use when you want lots of pro SFX quickly and do not need tight searching.

zapsplat.name: ZapSplat
zapsplat.short_description: Large library of SFX and some music. Free tier typically requires attribution; paid removes attribution for many assets.
zapsplat.license_notes: Attribution is commonly required on free accounts; some assets are CC0. Check the license type on each download.
zapsplat.beginner_tip: If you cannot or will not do attribution credits, treat ZapSplat as lower priority unless CC0 or paid.

youtube_audio_library.name: YouTube Audio Library
youtube_audio_library.short_description: Free music and SFX provided for creators. Useful and safe, but you must follow YouTube’s specific usage notes.
youtube_audio_library.license_notes: Some tracks require attribution; terms vary by track. Check the specific track’s requirements before using in a shipped game.
youtube_audio_library.beginner_tip: Good backup option. Screenshot or save the track’s license/attribution requirement for your records.

incompetech.name: Incompetech (Kevin MacLeod)
incompetech.short_description: Classic free game music source. Lots of usable tracks, especially for prototypes and simple releases.
incompetech.license_notes: Typically free with attribution; paid license removes attribution requirements.
incompetech.beginner_tip: If you use it in a commercial game, keep a clean credits file and follow the exact attribution format.

free_music_archive.name: Free Music Archive
free_music_archive.short_description: Music library where licenses vary by track. Good variety, but requires careful filtering for commercial use.
free_music_archive.license_notes: Many tracks use Creative Commons licenses. You must filter out NC for commercial projects and follow attribution rules when required.
free_music_archive.beginner_tip: Only use tracks that clearly allow commercial use.

ccmixter.name: ccMixter
ccmixter.short_description: Creative Commons music community. Quality varies, licensing varies, but can be great for free music with clear license labels.
ccmixter.license_notes: Track licenses vary. Some require attribution, some restrict commercial use.
ccmixter.beginner_tip: Filter for licenses that explicitly allow commercial use, then store attribution details.

poly_haven.name: Poly Haven
poly_haven.short_description: Top-tier CC0 textures, HDRIs, and some models. Very safe licensing and great quality for 3D games.
poly_haven.license_notes: CC0 content intended for unrestricted use (including commercial), no attribution required.
poly_haven.beginner_tip: If you are doing 3D, start here for textures first.

ambientcg.name: ambientCG
ambientcg.short_description: Huge CC0 library of PBR textures plus some models. Extremely useful for 3D environments.
ambientcg.license_notes: CC0, no attribution required, including commercial use.
ambientcg.beginner_tip: Great second stop after Poly Haven if you cannot find the exact material you need.

texturecan.name: TextureCan
texturecan.short_description: Free PBR textures and some CC0 models. Solid selection, clear CC0 positioning.
texturecan.license_notes: Stated as CC0 for offered textures and graphics.
texturecan.beginner_tip: Good for filling gaps when Poly Haven and ambientCG do not have what you want.

sharetextures.name: ShareTextures
sharetextures.short_description: Free textures and models with CC0 positioning plus platform ToS constraints. Useful, but read their terms.
sharetextures.license_notes: Claims CC0 licensing, but also has platform terms around redistribution/collection-style reuploads.
sharetextures.beginner_tip: Using inside your game is fine, but do not reupload their packs elsewhere.

3dtextures_me.name: 3DTextures.me
3dtextures_me.short_description: Free texture site with CC0 explanations. Good for additional PBR materials.
3dtextures_me.license_notes: CC0 is emphasized; still verify per download page when possible.
3dtextures_me.beginner_tip: Great for quick materials, especially if you need lots of variants.

cgbookcase.name: CGBookcase
cgbookcase.short_description: Free PBR textures with an emphasis on no restrictions. Smaller than ambientCG, but useful.
cgbookcase.license_notes: Site presents textures as free with no restrictions; still keep a record of the asset source.

textures_com.name: Textures.com
textures_com.short_description: Huge professional texture library with a free plan, but not CC0 and comes with more usage constraints.
textures_com.license_notes: Allowed for commercial games, including with free account downloads, but the license is not public domain and has rules.
textures_com.beginner_tip: Use if you need something very specific, but prefer CC0 libraries first.

quaternius.name: Quaternius
quaternius.short_description: Stylized low-poly 3D packs that are popular for prototypes and simple releases.
quaternius.license_notes: Commonly positioned as free for commercial use; verify the pack’s license text per download.
quaternius.beginner_tip: Perfect for fast 3D prototyping without art bottlenecks.

kaylousberg.name: Kay Lousberg (KayKit)
kaylousberg.short_description: Extremely useful low-poly packs for prototyping, often CC0 and designed for game engines.
kaylousberg.license_notes: Many packs are explicitly CC0 (no attribution required), but confirm per pack page.
kaylousberg.beginner_tip: If you want a clean low-poly style, this is one of the fastest paths.

polypizza.name: Poly Pizza
polypizza.short_description: 3D model library that aggregates assets. Licensing is per model, so you must check each asset.
polypizza.license_notes: Assets use Creative Commons licenses per asset. Not automatically CC0, so verify before using commercially.
polypizza.beginner_tip: Treat it like a search engine for models, not a single-license library.

sketchfab.name: Sketchfab
sketchfab.short_description: Huge model platform with downloadable models, some under Creative Commons. Great variety, but license varies.
sketchfab.license_notes: Many models are under different Creative Commons licenses. You must confirm license per model download.
sketchfab.beginner_tip: Only download models that explicitly allow commercial use (prefer CC0 or CC BY).

mixamo.name: Adobe Mixamo
mixamo.short_description: Free characters and animations for prototyping and even shipped games, but not a CC0 asset site.
mixamo.license_notes: Usable in projects, but you cannot redistribute the raw assets as a library. License is not CC0.
mixamo.beginner_tip: Use for characters fast, but do not rely on it as your only long-term art style.

game_icons_net.name: Game-Icons.net
game_icons_net.short_description: Large set of game-relevant SVG icons. Great for UI and ability icons.
game_icons_net.license_notes: Typically CC BY, so attribution is required.
game_icons_net.beginner_tip: If you hate credits, pick CC0 icon sources instead.

material_icons.name: Google Material Symbols / Icons
material_icons.short_description: Clean, consistent icons. Great for UI, menus, and non-fantasy visual language.
material_icons.license_notes: Apache 2.0 licensing for Material Icons is widely used and commercial-friendly.
material_icons.beginner_tip: Use when you want simple UI clarity over game-y style.

font_awesome.name: Font Awesome Free
font_awesome.short_description: Well-known icon set. Useful for UI icons, especially tool-style interfaces and menus.
font_awesome.license_notes: Free tier exists; licensing differs by component (icons vs code). Check the specific license page for your use.
font_awesome.beginner_tip: Good for clean UI, not great for fantasy RPG ability icons.

heroicons.name: Heroicons
heroicons.short_description: Modern, clean SVG icons. More web-app style than game style, but good for UI clarity.
heroicons.beginner_tip: Great for tooling UI and minimalist games.

svgrepo.name: SVG Repo
svgrepo.short_description: Huge icon aggregator. Many items are public domain/CC0, but licensing varies by icon source.
svgrepo.license_notes: You must check the license badge per icon (public domain/CC0 vs other licenses).
svgrepo.beginner_tip: Only download icons clearly marked public domain/CC0 if you want zero attribution.

openclipart.name: OpenClipart
openclipart.short_description: Public-domain style clipart. Can help for UI, icons, and placeholder art, but style consistency varies a lot.
openclipart.license_notes: CC0-based upload policy. Still inspect each asset for obvious trademark issues.
openclipart.beginner_tip: Best as placeholder art or for simple UI elements.

flaticon.name: Flaticon
flaticon.short_description: Huge icon library, but many assets are paywalled and free use often requires attribution and has limits.
flaticon.license_notes: Attribution commonly required on free tier; many premium-only assets.
flaticon.beginner_tip: Use only if you accept attribution or pay. Otherwise pick CC0/MIT/Apache sources.

itchio_cc0.name: itch.io (CC0 asset listings)
itchio_cc0.short_description: A discovery hub for CC0 game assets from many creators (2D, 3D, UI, textures, audio).
itchio_cc0.license_notes: The CC0 section is safest. Outside CC0, licenses vary per asset/creator and you must read each page.
itchio_cc0.beginner_tip: Use the CC0 filters to avoid licensing headaches.

craftpix.name: CraftPix
craftpix.short_description: High-quality 2D packs (sprites, UI, icons). Has freebies, but a lot is premium or membership-based.
craftpix.license_notes: Claims commercial use allowed, but it is a store model. Always read their license details per download/product.
craftpix.beginner_tip: Good for polish, but not the first stop if you want pure CC0 simplicity.

openverse.name: Openverse
openverse.short_description: Search engine for Creative Commons content (images and audio). Best used when you need a specific thing and can filter by license.
openverse.license_notes: Aggregates CC-licensed content. You must follow the source license and attribution rules.
openverse.beginner_tip: Use as a last-mile search tool after the dedicated game-asset sites.

unity_asset_store.name: Unity Asset Store
unity_asset_store.short_description: Massive library for everything (2D, 3D, audio, textures), but licensing is not CC0 and redistribution rules are strict.
unity_asset_store.license_notes: Standard EULA style licensing; generally you can ship games using assets, but cannot redistribute raw assets as asset packs.
unity_asset_store.beginner_tip: Great for speed, but store the invoice/license proof and avoid anything you cannot legally include in a repo.

Sound effects.why: Game-ready SFX packs, beginner-friendly, typically CC0.
Huge pro-quality bundles, commercial-friendly, no attribution in practice.
Easy, free, no attribution in typical use; wide selection.
Largest searchable library, but license varies per sound. Use CC0 filter.
Safe source for creators, but track requirements vary.
Good selection, but mixed licenses and inconsistent quality.
Large library, but free tier usually requires attribution.
Great CC0 discovery, but less centralized searching than dedicated audio sites.
Lots of free SFX packs, but stricter EULA and not CC0.
Good for finding specific CC audio, but you must verify source licenses carefully.

Music.why: Fast downloads, broad library, commercial-friendly baseline.
Reliable classic library; free with attribution or paid to remove it.
Solid free music; some tracks require attribution.
Good variety, but licenses vary and quality is inconsistent.
Good discovery, but you must filter to commercial-allowed licenses.
Creative Commons library; licensing varies but usually explicit.
Music exists, but free tier often requires attribution.
Some great CC0 music packs exist; discovery is the main advantage.
Aggregator, helpful when you need something specific and can filter licenses.

3d models.why: Excellent low-poly prototyping packs; many explicitly CC0.
Fast stylized packs for prototypes and simple shipped games; check pack license.
High-quality models with CC0, strong legal safety.
CC0 models plus textures; very useful for environments.
CC0 models and textures; good fill-in library.
CC0 positioning with platform ToS; still very usable for games.
Great variety, but license is per model and not always CC0.
Huge selection, but licensing varies widely. Must filter carefully.
Great for character prototyping, but not a CC0 asset library and has redistribution limits.
Lots of free models, but EULA-based licensing and restrictions on redistribution.
Strong CC0 packs exist; discovery-focused rather than a single library.

Vector icons.why: Game UI packs with consistent style, often includes vector sources, typically CC0.
MIT licensed, clean icons, great for minimal UI.
Huge library, but license varies per icon. Prefer public domain/CC0 icons.
Very useful UI icons; licensing differs by component and many icons are premium.
Very game-relevant icons but typically requires attribution (CC BY).
CC0 but style consistency is random; best for placeholders.
Freemium with common attribution requirements and paywalls.
Good for CC0 UI/icon packs from creators.

2d art/sprites.why: Best beginner choice: clean packs, consistent style, typically CC0.
Huge variety, but filter hard for commercial-safe licenses.
Great CC0 discovery for sprites/tilesets/UI from many creators.
Good quality freebies, but much is premium and license is store-based.
CC0 clipart can work for UI and placeholders, but game-ready sprites vary.
Can help for backgrounds and general art, but not game-sprite focused.
Good search layer if you need a specific thing and can filter by license.
Many free 2D packs, but EULA-based, not CC0, and style is inconsistent.

Textures.why: Top quality + CC0. Best legal simplicity for commercial projects.
Massive CC0 PBR library, excellent coverage.
CC0 positioning plus ToS constraints; still great for games.
Good backup library, free textures with no-restriction positioning.
Allowed for games even on free account, but not CC0 and has stricter rules.
Surprisingly good CC0 texture packs exist, discovery is the advantage.
Many texture packs, but EULA restrictions and inconsistent quality.
Aggregator, useful when you need something specific and can filter licenses.
